item.title: How to elevate your travel photography
item.description: Helpful travel photography tips from the pros
item.dc:creator: Alex Begin
item.content:encoded:
For most of us, the urge to take photos has never been stronger than when we’re travelling. The best travel photos can bring us back to cherished memories of past trips, or even transport us to places we’ve never experienced first-hand. But when it comes to travel photography, the truth is: while we all do it — few do it well.  So if you’re looking to take your travel photography to the next level, you’re in the right place.

We recently caught up with a few of our favourite travel photographers on Unsplash to chat about everything from their travel photography gear when travelling, to their top tips for the beginners out there.

But first, why travel photography?

For Unsplash contributor Gene Brutty, travel photography is less about the excitement of being in a new place, and more about capturing “another person’s ‘normal’.” Gene says, “Typical and common tourist attractions often misrepresent the essence of a city or town. True travel photography ventures beyond tourist hotspots and explores the side streets, and unsassuming locations to really capture the heart of the place.”

Daniel Schwarz appreciates the added goal or end mission when he’s travelling. He says, “You want to get the most stunning shot, which also motivates you to go that extra mile — and you end up discovering more than you would have!”

Ryunosuke Kikuno is in awe of travel photography’s ability to connect the world: “The best part of travel photos is the way they allow us to experience the world around us as if you’re there yourself.”

Unsplash contributor Mehmet Turgut Kirkgoz first started delving into travel photography because of, as he puts it, “the excitement of discovery.” He explains, “I love travel photography because the photo can describe the people, culture and natural state of that place — a photo does not contain geographical borders.”

Essential photography gear when on the road

With travel photography, it’s often a fine balance between bringing the gear you need, and the gear that’s comfortable to carry. For this reason, Gene keeps it simple and opts for his Sony a7R  III and two lenses (Sony 24-70mm GM, and Sony 85mm).

Unsplash contributor Ryunosuke’s camera of choice? The Nikon Z6 II. He’ll also typically travel with three lenses: NIKKOR Z "24-70mm F4 /S", "24mm F1.8 /S", "40mm F2. He says, “I especially love the 24mm f/1.8 / S that I bought for shooting landscapes because it provides a really great rendering.” And last, he’ll bring a tripod because “it’s essential for nighttime photography.”

Daniel says  the most important thing for him is “to have reliable gear that can withstand sandstorms or rain.” He uses his Canon 6D Mark II with a Tamron 24-70mm F/2.8 Di VC USD G2 Lens and an iPhone 11.

The challenges of travel photography

For most, the challenge (and beauty) of travel photography revolves around shooting unfamiliar places. This is why Mehmet believes the most important part to travel photography is studying the destination beforehand and bringing the right equipment. He says, “Do a preliminary study of the region to be travelled and examine the photos taken before about that region. Pre-design the compositions and set up the equipment.”

While it often pays to prepare and plan, Ryunosuke admits, “It won’t always be possible to take the photos you envision.” But often, these challenges can become ways to capture new places in unique ways. On a past trip to Vancouver,

Ryunosuke recounts: “It rained the entire time I was there. However, I used the puddles that appeared to take some nice reflection photography. Even unexpected moments like that can make travel photography even more enjoyable depending on your way of thinking.”

Top tips for beginners looking to improve their travel photos

Daniel’s top tip? Know your camera. He warns, “Don’t let the camera occupy the moments. Know your equipment so you don’t waste time on technical stuff.“ Then, it all comes down to patience. Remember that “you are not in a studio, you have to wait until the clouds or sun are at a place you want them to be.”

With Gene, it’s simple: Walk. “Walk everywhere if possible. Walk aimlessly, walk slowly, take the long way on purpose - the unexpected moments you will uncover by doing this will be better than any photo you plan for.”

For Ryunosuke, it’s all about experimenting with different perspectives. “Try boldly moving  closer or further away. Play around with extreme low or high angles or from directly below or above your subject without relying solely on the camera's lens zoom. Then, it will be able to take own special or unique travel photography that are different from those than always.”

Fondest photographs from past travels

A photograph from Gene’s travels in Mumbai continues to stick with him, even now. He recounts, “I was in a car on my way to a work meeting when I saw two small children living on the corner of an enormous intersection. It was a really confronting scene that I couldn’t ignore.” While his original intention was to capture the entire intersection, his car crossed the busy street too quickly: “Instead, I chose to capture this really sweet and intimate moment between two children, and focus on the fact they had each other.”

Daniel’s most memorable photograph was taken after a long hike getting caught in the rain back from Preikestolen, Norway.  After a few hours of waiting in their vans, a beautiful rainbow showed up above their camp spot. He says, “It was the perfect example of never being able to predict what shot you’ll get, and sometimes it will turn out better than you ever thought!”

For Mehmet, his most cherished photos are from his travels in Nepal. He says, “The people are sincere and kind, the colors and texture are gorgeous.”

One particular photograph has the power to instantly transport Ryunosuke back to a fond memory from his past trip to Vancouver. He remembers “that it was cloudy all that day but being very impressed by the beauty of the foliage that dispelled the overcast. The scenery created by the autumn leaves is wonderful, nostalgic, and giving a deeply inspiring.”

Ultimately, what’s the key to great travel photography?

For Gene, it’s all about going beyond the classic tourist shots and “pick subject matters that tell a story.” He says, “Photograph something that no postcard, or travel brochure, or lonely planet guide would think of capturing.”

And Ryunosuke believes the key to great travel photography, is actually enjoying the process. He says, “Don’t take travel photos out of a sense of obligation because it’s a trip. No amount of technique or gear can replace your passion for the subject matter.”

Most importantly? Daniel says, “Never forget that you travel to soak up new things, to learn and grow, and to live your life — it’s not all about taking that 100% polished shot. You will associate some great moments with every photo you take!”

item.title: Meet the Unsplash team: Roberta Doyle
item.description: 10 questions with Roberta from the Unsplash Product team
item.dc:creator: Natalie Brennan
item.content:encoded:
Who are you and what’s your role at Unsplash?

I'm Roberta, a software engineer on the API team.

When did you join the team?

December 2016, feels like a lifetime ago!

Where do you live?

Briançon, France but I'm originally from Brazil.

Who do you primarily work with on the team?

My lovely co-workers on the API team. I tend to interact more with Bruno because of the timezone, he's in Uruguay so a bit "closer" to my European time.

Why do you enjoy working on Unsplash?

Being able to work on different features and have a real impact on the product. As well as the Unsplash culture, work flexibility and ownership.

What is your favourite thing you worked on Unsplash?

I'm at my happiest place when I'm working with search. My favourite thing was probably when we changed the search algorithm to consider confidence for the tags of a given photo.

What do you like to listen to while you work?

It changes ... mostly what Spotify added to my Discover Weekly, sometimes Brazilian music and lately French songs to help improve my French :)

Favourite working snack?

Depends on the season, but lately, I've been loving dried figs.

What do you do when you're not working on Unsplash?

Cooking, enjoying nature, spending time with my dogs and climbing.

item.title: The Color of Water
item.description: It's time to reveal dirty water’s true colors.
item.dc:creator: Unsplash Team
item.content:encoded:
Today marks World Water Day, a very important day for our new Unsplash for Good partner, charity: water whose goal is simple: bring clean and safe drinking water to every person on the planet. In order to do that, we need to wake people up to the fact that 771 million people in the world still do not have access to clean water.

“Since charity: water was founded in 2006, we’ve been chasing one ambitious goal: ending the global water crisis. And while the water crisis is huge, we’re optimistic. We know how to solve the problem, and we make progress every day thanks to the help of local partners and generous supporters. If we work together, we believe everyone will have access to life’s most basic need within our lifetime.”
— charity: water

This year, they’ve put together an awareness campaign called The Color of Dirty Water to help paint a picture of the real color of water that too many people around the world drink today. There is water in countries where they work that is milky gray, mustard yellow, and forest green. Colors that look beautiful on a Pantone tile or accent wall but are unbelievably shocking when poured into a glass.

That’s where you come in.

Our plan: Rally the support of the Unsplash community to reveal dirty water’s true colors and bring awareness to the world water crisis through a new topic, Color of Water.

Color of Water

Inspired by trips to communities around the world, charity: water has identified five different shades of water. Appropriately kicking off on World Water Day (March 22) and ending on Earth Day (April 22);  submit your most striking BROWN, GREEN, RED, GRAY and YELLOW images to match the colors of dirty water.

The subject matter can be anything (it doesn’t have to be a liquid) and our goal is to highlight that although your coffee, cat, or even car may be that color, water shouldn’t be.

Unsplash and charity: water will be highlighting their favorite 3 photographs for each color as campaign imagery on the charity: water website and on our social channels in the month to come.

To take this impact even further, we are partnering with our friends at Boxed Water, who are going to donate $1 per approved submission (up to $2500) to charity: water. This donation will go towards funding a water project in helping a community get access to clean water.

The 5 colors of water & where they’re found

Green

About a third of the world's poor live in India, battling blatant gender and class inequalities to climb out of poverty. Safe drinking water and improved sanitation can give these families a chance for healthier, happier lives.

Red

While Madagascar’s rich biodiversity draws environmental and conservation attention, the people who live there are often overlooked. Basic access to clean drinking water sits at just 54% throughout the country and drops to 36% in rural areas. Sanitation and hygiene access is no better. Coupled with regular floods, droughts, and cyclones, basic health and safety can be hard to come by.

Yellow

As the largest country in West Africa, Niger has over three billion cubic meters of drinkable water available underground. The problem is, few can afford to build systems to bring it to the surface.

Around half of Niger’s population lives below the poverty line. Between the desert landscape and shortage of clean water, farming—and life—are difficult throughout the country. These are some of the reasons Niger consistently ranks near the bottom of the U.N. Human Development Index.

Brown

Cambodia has plenty of available groundwater; the problem is that not much of it is safe enough to drink. Many ponds or open wells are contaminated with industrial runoff, human waste, or contaminants like arsenic and E. coli bacteria.

Gray

Northern Uganda is still rebounding after two decades of civil war. More than 1.6 million people were internally displaced (80% were women and children) and many remain far from home today.

But clean water projects can improve health, shorten the time spent walking for water, and even help define and rebuild communities returning to or looking for a home after years of displacement.

Submit to the Color of Water Topic

Go ahead — submit your most striking YELLOW, RED, BROWN, GREEN, or GRAY images (of any subject matter) directly to the topic for a chance to be featured. Submissions are open now until April 22, 2022.

  • Head over to the Color of Water Topic on Unsplash
  • Hit the “Submit to Color of Water Topic” button
  • Submit any photos you’ve shot that meet our Submission Guidelines.
  • The top images from each color will be featured online and across both Unsplash and charity: water social channels.
  • Terms & Conditions apply.

↪Submit to the Color Water Topic

Help us make an impact

Help us spread the message by showing your support on social.  Download png templates here to use alongside your (or anyone’s) Unsplash image.

Use the caption:
“[Your item] might be [this color]. But water shouldn’t be.

In honor of #WorldWaterDay, @charitywater is revealing dirty water’s true colors. Learn more and get everything you need to help spread the word at charitywater.org/dirtywater.”.

Examples:

  • Beer might be this color, but water shouldn't be.
  • Succulents might be this color, but water shouldn't be.
  • Coffee might be this color, but water shouldn't be.

If you want to join Boxed Water in financially supporting the cause, you can donate directly to charity: water at charitywater.org.

How does Unsplash for Good work?

Unsplash for Good supports charities and organizations by building awareness on global issues through visual content. Focusing on causes such as environmental concerns and social injustices, let’s create a global impact by using Unsplash for Good.

Do you want to get involved with Unsplash for Good? Reach out: we’d love to make magic happen — partnerships@unsplash.com

item.title: Meet the Unsplash Team : Aaron Klaassen
item.description: 10 questions with Aaron from the Unsplash API team
item.dc:creator: Natalie Brennan
item.content:encoded:
Who are you and what’s your role at Unsplash?

I'm Head of API. The team works on (surprise) the Unsplash API, but more generally all of our backend infrastructure.

When did you join the team?

2015! April, I think? We were all little babies back then, remember? Unsplash included.

Where do you live?

Right here in sunny Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Where do you work?

I've got a pretty run-of-the-mill home office, so that's where I spend the bulk of my workdays. In the Before Times I'd often spend at least an afternoon or two a week working from a cafe or coworking space, something just to change up the scenery a bit. Hopefully back to that consistently again soon, right?

Who do you primarily work with on the team?

Mostly just the other members of the API team - Bruno, Roberta, Cristian, Andrii - though I get plenty of overlap with the other leads and the API partnerships team.

Why do you enjoy working on Unsplash?

I've said it before, but I like making things that help people make things. And I mean that both in the sense that Unsplash gives people access to a photo library, but also the API more specifically that enables building or integrating software that uses Unsplash.

What is your favorite thing you worked on at Unsplash?

Whew, that's a big question; we do our best not to silo knowledge (and we're a small team besides) so I've probably touched every part of the app over the years. Nonetheless - and maybe this is just me being a masochist - but I get a lot of satisfaction out of really getting into the weeds figuring out weird obscure bugs, and then writing up a whole danged treatise on my journey in the description of the fix.

This assumes that I do in fact succeed in getting to a fix, which is maybe a dubious assumption.

What do you do when you aren’t working on Unsplash?

I build scale models. Not so much kits out-of-box much anymore - instead it's mostly scratchbuilding or kitbashing scifi space ships and robots and stuff. Been slowly getting more into more scenic diorama projects; I'm just wrapping up a fairy house diorama as a gift for my mom, but that's still a surprise which means now that I've written this down I have to make sure she doesn't read this.

Describe yourself using 3 emojis

Where can people find you/chat to you?

Twitter, I suppose: @aaronklaassen

item.title: Back to Basics: How to shoot screens
item.description: Unsplash curator and contributor, Nik Jones, shares 6 tips on shooting digital screens.
item.dc:creator: Unsplash Team
item.content:encoded:
Some of the most-searched-for photos on Unsplash revolve around tech — from photos of coding to images of go-to apps like Twitter or Instagram. Shooting photos of apps on your desktop or mobile screens is a great way to gain visibility on Unsplash — but taking a good photo of your digital screens can be trickier than it may seem. For anyone who’s tried, you’ll know all too well that the end result is often plagued with unfortunate glare or static lines across the image.

Unsplash Curator and photographer Nik Jones is no stranger to shooting her favorite apps — in fact, some of her most popular photos on Unsplash showcase tech. So we’ve asked her to walk us through some of her top tips to capturing great photos of screens.

Tip 1: Clean your screen!

First thing’s first: This may seem obvious — but I’ll say it anyway: Make sure your screens are free of fingerprints, dust, or smudges before your photoshoot. And even if they look fine at first glance, give your screens a good clean as your camera will pick up on everything. To clean my screen, I typically use the cloths you get to clean your glasses. If that doesn’t work, I use screen wipes designed for your digital screens to get off stubborn grime.

Tip 2: Set the scene

Whether you’re shooting your phone screen or your desktop monitor — pay attention to what else will make it into the frame. Is your desk littered with crumpled papers? Are any post-its with your passwords on show? Make sure the surroundings feel natural and intentional.

Tip 3: Use soft natural light

That pesky glare we mentioned? That can be avoided by shooting LCD screens in soft natural light. Artificial lighting will inevitably give off more glare — but if natural lighting isn’t available, be sure you experiment with the angle of your phone and camera. And make sure your phone never has direct light hitting it to avoid unwanted glare. The secret to getting great photos of your screens is truly all about getting the right angle.

Tip 4: Try a small aperture

Use a small aperture so the whole screen is in focus. If you're holding your phone in your hand, you’ll be able to retain a good depth of field while keeping the phone as the main subject. If you’re shooting your desktop, I typically make sure the screen isn’t too close to my camera, and experiment with the angles so you can minimize reflections and have a nice depth of field in the background.

Tip 5: Turn down screen brightness

To avoid overexposing your shots, turn down your screen brightness accordingly. This will ensure that your photos remain balanced. Another option? Shoot a few photos in dark mode.

Tip 6: Minimize reflections

While some reflections are okay, others can feel like they detract from the final image. To reduce jarring reflections, you can hold a dark reflector between your light source and your screen. You don’t need a fancy kit to achieve great results, I use a little piece of black card as my reflector which has served me well!

While taking photos of digital screens can take a little experimentation, it’s a great way to test your photography skills and try out new photoshoot ideas. It also happens to be a great way to fill gaps in the Unsplash library (which means your photos will get seen fast)!

Try it out!

Submit your very own photos of mobile or desktop screens to our new Digital Screens Topic for a chance to be featured on the topic (and have a higher chance of being promoted on the homepage Editorial feed).

item.title: Meet the Unsplash team: Thomas Lefebvre
item.description: 10 questions with Thomas from the Unsplash web team
item.dc:creator: Natalie Brennan
item.content:encoded:
Who are you and what’s your role at Unsplash?

Hey, my name is Thomas, you might also know me as Bear. It’s a nickname the team gave me after I’ve posted a photo of a bear on Unsplash many years ago.

I work as a software developer on the web team, the user-facing part of Unsplash.com. If you ever clicked on a button and nothing happened, it’s probably a bug I introduced.

When did you join the team?

My story with Unsplash starts in around 2014 when I first got hired as a backend developer for our parent company back in the days, Crew. Remember that photo of a bear I posted? That’s what got me introduced to Unsplash, then Crew, and I still believe it helped me get the job.

Back then, Unsplash was just a Tumblr blog and I’ve followed closely its growth from the very early days, seeing it change from a “10 free photos every 10 days” to what it is today.

I haven’t been actually working on Unsplash from the beginning, I’ve explored other products out there to come back working with this amazing team, folks I knew and some I didn’t, in 2020.

Where do you live?

I currently live in Montreal, QC, Canada. I was born Belgian and soon to be Canadian (gentle reminder to the Canadian government to finish processing my application, thank you).

Who do you primarily work with on the team?

I’ll say mainly my teammates in the web team (Olly, Sam and Nim) and outside of web I think Kirill. We’re a pretty small team so I think we all talk to each other regularly.

Why do you enjoy working on Unsplash?

I obviously like the product and the impact it has on the community. Photography has always been a little side passion of me but most importantly I really enjoy the culture we’ve created. Everyone has the flexibility of working however they like, whenever they like. No set hours, no time tracking, unlimited vacations (it actually is true). We were remote-friendly before it was cool. We believe people know best how and when to do their best work. This is the kind of culture I was looking for and to this day I use it to the fullest (skiing in the middle of the week, anyone?)

What is your favorite thing you worked on at Unsplash?

Hard to say, there are so many, but I will say that what I’m currently working on right now is really exciting. I can’t really say anything but I think it’ll make Unsplash more inclusive and I’m excited for more people to be able to use it!

What do you like to listen to while you work?

Ouf, that’s a tough one. Honestly, it can range from LoFi to House, funk to Taylor Swift, and sometimes podcasts. It really depends on my mood and what I’m currently doing. Right now I’m listening to Jazz :). One song that I listened to a lot while building Unsplash is “The Other Side Of Paradise” from Glass animals.

What do you do when you aren’t working on Unsplash?

Good question. I like doing outdoor stuff, just started learning how to snowboard and people were right, you do fall a lot. Otherwise, I like chess. I also used to play much more video games but I still enjoy it quite a bit. Taking care of my plants, doing some homemade interior design plans. I’ve also started making candles! Cooking all the good stuff, I recently made tonkotsu ramen.

Describe yourself using 3 emojis

Where can people find you/chat with you?

You can find me on Twitter, IG and here’s also my Github! I’m usually pretty good at answering so feel free to drop me a message.

item.title: Unsplash + UNEP
item.description: We need to Act For Nature now, so it can still exist 50 years from now.
item.dc:creator: Unsplash Team
item.content:encoded:
Nature photography has always been so important to the Unsplash community. Given increasing climate concerns, capturing the natural world has never been more crucial.

That’s why our first Unsplash for Good initiative is an exciting partnership with the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP).

“For 50 years UNEP has coordinated a worldwide effort to confront the planet’s biggest environmental challenges. UNEP’s convening power and rigorous scientific research has provided a platform for countries to engage, act boldly and advance the global environmental agenda.” - UNEP

We are thrilled they’ve asked the Unsplash community to take part in this worldwide effort, by promoting the importance of taking care of our planet through imagery.  

Our plan: In honor of UNEP’s 50th anniversary this year, we are launching a new Act For Nature Topic for you to submit images of the landscapes you still want to be around 50 years from now.

UNEP will be selecting the 15 images that best reflect the beauty of our planet. They are looking for diverse landscapes showcasing the wonders that span the globe. The selected images will be featured in an online gallery on the UNEP website.

The topic kicks off today, March 3rd, as part of the UN Environment Assembly and UNEP@50 event, and runs for one month.

Need inspiration? Head to the Topic to see some great examples.

Submit to the Act For Nature Topic

Go ahead — submit your best landscape shots directly to the topic for a chance to be featured. Submissions are open now until April 3, 2022.

  • Head over to the Act For Nature Topic on Unsplash
  • Hit the “Submit to Act For Nature Topic” button
  • Submit any photos you’ve shot that meet our Submission Guidelines.
  • The top 15 images, chosen by UNEP, will be featured in an online gallery on the UNEP website.

Unsplash for Good supports charities and organizations by building awareness on global issues through visual content. Focusing on causes such as environmental concerns and social injustices, let’s create a global impact by using Unsplash for Good.

item.title: Unsplash + Unbounce
item.description: Bringing 3 million+ high-quality images to Unbounce's all-new Smart Builder.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Brennan
item.content:encoded:
Unsplash was born out of the mission of making something difficult (finding usable images) a whole lot easier — fast-forward to a global library of over 3 million free images. Unbounce, a landing page builder and platform for smarter marketing, shares that same vision.

Undeniably, uniting Unsplash and Unbounce will further uncover ways to uncomplicate your life. (see what we did there? 😏)

Unbounce just launched ‘Unbounce Apps’, as a growing library of tools to help your business. Unbounce Apps offer a variety of features and functionalities within the Unbounce Conversion Intelligence™ Platform that you can easily add to your Smart Builder landing pages.

And we are thrilled to have Unsplash be one of the first Unbounce Apps available on the platform.

Adding an Unsplash image to your Unbounce landing page

Unsplash is already the go-to stock image library for business owners and marketers using Unbounce’s Smart Builder. This integration provides a huge library of high-quality images brought by Unsplash’s community of over 300,000 photographers, making it easier than ever to add free images to a landing page in just a few clicks.

To find the perfect Unsplash image:

  1. Go to Image Properties (paintbrush icon).
  2. Click the + icon.
  3. Go to Unsplash Image option.
  4. Search for your perfect image and click on it to add it to your landing page.


Unbounce gives you the tools to create smarter online marketing campaigns. And now with Unsplash images directly accessible within Unbounce  —  the possibilities are truly endless.

More on Unsplash Partnerships. This is part of our continued mission to enable creativity by making quality visuals openly accessible.

10000+ partners including Squarespace, Medium, Dropbox, Trello, Adobe, Google, Sketch, Square, Wix, InVision, Typeform, PicsArt, WeTransfer, BuzzFeed, support this mission by officially integrating with the Unsplash API.🔥

item.title: Unsplash + Surface
item.description: Capturing the drive and determination of entrepreneurship.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Brennan
item.content:encoded:
Entrepreneurship is not for the faint of heart. An entrepreneur’s innovation, ideation and strength are often met with long hours, financial stress and lack of sleep. That is why Microsoft Surface is taking over the Entrepreneur Topic to applaud the tireless effort that goes into owning a business.

From now until March 15th, submit images showcasing any part of the entrepreneurial journey — from starting on your couch with a laptop, to working late with endless cups of coffee, to commanding a board meeting for your employees.

The image that highlights the struggle of the entrepreneur story the best will have the chance at $500 USD.

Need some inspiration? Head to the Entrepreneur Topic.

Submit to the Entrepreneur Topic

Go ahead — submit your best Entrepreneur shots directly to the topic for a chance to be featured.

  • Hit the “Submit to Entrepreneur Topic” button
  • Submit any new photos you’ve shot that meet our Submission Guidelines.

item.title: Behind 1 Billion: Toa Heftiba
item.description: We caught up with contributor Toa Heftiba on how it feels to have reached 2 billion views on Unsplash.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Brennan
item.content:encoded:
"It’s a crazy number.. I wouldn’t even know how to write it with zeros... So, so grateful." says contributor, Toa Heftiba, on how it feels to have reached the mind-blowing milestone of 2 billion views (!).

In the third installment of our “Behind 1 Billion” mini series, we caught up with the new mom to chat about why she started on Unsplash and her favorite moments since joining the community.

Tell us a little about why and how you started submitting to Unsplash?

"I submitted my first picture in 2016, when my husband introduced me to Unsplash. He was pushing for me to upload my work on Unsplash, as he thought it would be ‘the new up and coming’ platform for photographers, and I would not only fit well with their vision and style, but would benefit from it — and boy was he right.

At a first glance, it all looked very intimidating and I did not feel confident enough to upload any pictures.  I did however upload 10 of my best pictures from our recent ski trip to get my husband off my back — the next day I received a notification on Instagram that Unsplash tagged me in a post. I remember the excitement like it was yesterday, I felt so seen and validated, to have them share one of my pictures when I didn’t think that my work would be of any use. There were tears of course.

It was the first platform that interacted with you as a user, it had that human factor, it made you feel celebrated rather than being used - this is number one reason why I continued uploading and being part of this community."

How do you feel your photography has grown since you started out on Unsplash?

"I think I grew in confidence the most, which reflects in my work. Being able to take part in bigger projects, like shooting for ‘Samsung’, and ‘Boxed Water is Better’ pushed me out of my comfort zone and stretched my limits. Photoclubs have also been a source of growth, and a place to form friendships."

What has been your most memorable experience on Unsplash?

"From a professional point of view, having the opportunity to create content for Samsung was my favourite experience. From a user point of view, it's the warm welcome I still feel after all these years of being part of this community."

Show Tezos together with other blockchain or crypto projects in your submission for a chance to win a prize! The top 20 images will be purchased and used for Tezos related initiatives and the contributors will be rewarded a prize. You can download the Tezos logo here.
